labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Questions from initial review of Introduction
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
- [ ] I didn't find "Payload" in RFC9261. Can you refer me to the document which is closest in the sense it is used?
- [x] I don't seem to understand the following sentence: 
> The end-entity certificate is associated with key material that serves as an Attestation Key, which acts as Evidence originating from the Attester.
- [x] Not sure about the following sentence: Why not from the client? Are you scoping to a specific scenario, e.g., server/client as Attester or something else? This needs some explanation. 
> The mechanisms described in this document focus primarily on the server's ability to generate TLS Exported Authenticators.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Hi Usama, I've taken the liberty to make checkboxes from your points above to track them more easily, but it turns out all of the issues are now gone, probably fixed in a newer version of the draft. If you'd like, you can check as well. Otherwise, feel free to close this.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
Thanks, the last 2 sub-issues are indeed fixed. About the first one, I still see the "payload" in the editor draft. 

> CMW provides a structured encapsulation of Evidence and Attestation Result payloads, abstracting the underlying attestation technology.

Maybe some PR replaces it; else I want to understand what exactly does it mean. For example, what is the difference between `Evidence` and `Evidence payload`?

issues.title: Define Key Attestation in terminology
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body: I am not yet sure in what sense key attestation is used in the draft. I think you mean workload attestation instead? Particularly the key in Confidential Computing does not exist at initial measurement time (load-time measurement), and hence I think the key -- per se -- cannot be "attested".

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body:
Alternatively copy the definition of "key attestation" from draft-bft-rats-kat:

> Evidence containing properties of the environment(s) in which the
      private keys are stored.  For example, a Relying Party may want to
      know whether a private key is stored in a hardware security module
      and cannot be exported in unencrypted fashion.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: I'm leaning towards removing any references to key attestation from the document, as I'm unsure what the value add of attesting keys is in this context. We're making it clear that there has to be some network identity key available to the attester, along with a certificate for it (since the attestation credential is only in an extension of the Certificate message). The binding between RA and TLS also doesn't happen through this key, but through the exported material.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I'm pretty sure that we still want to say that the key used for signing the handshake is guaranteed to have the property of being protected by the TEE, and that this can be proven by means of attestation.
This is what I believe "key attestation” means, or at least how I intend it.
If the term is confusing, I am happy to remove it.
However, whenever we use the term “attestation” or “evidence” in the context of the document, the above property should be clearly implied.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
> I'm pretty sure that we still want to say that the key used for signing the handshake is guaranteed to have the property of being protected by the TEE, and that this can be proven by means of attestation.

I don't know if key attestation in particular makes this easier or not. For key attestation to be valid you need to:

1. attest the key (which I assume is daisy-chained via hashes to the platform and/or workload tokens)
2. send the attestation credential to the RP
3. get the RP to understand the credential _and_ trust that the code enforces what the credential says about the key (i.e., that it's protected by the TEE)

But for point (3) if the RP understands and trusts all that about the attester (via its measurements), what's the difference from just having regular workload attestation and relying on measurements of the networking stack to infer that the key used is indeed in the TEE. The RP _needs_ to know that anyway (and can infer it), without explicitly binding the key in the evidence.

I guess we're both after the same guarantee, just that you're looking for explicit attestation and I'm settling for implicit attestation :grin:

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
> I guess we're both after the same guarantee, just that you're looking for explicit attestation and I'm settling for implicit attestation

Also, implicit is probably far more rough in what it can convey, perhaps only one bit ("in TEE"). So depends if you want/need more metadata about the key (provenance, security policy...)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Sure, I don’t think explicit vs implicit is the discriminant here.  The important thing is to clearly state that the RP needs to check that the “protection of the signing key” property is satisfied.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Cool, I'll update the PR to reflect this! Thanks!

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: All instances of "key attestation" are now removed. Closing the issue.

issues.title: Separate Client-Side Attester?
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body: What does it mean to have a "Separate Client-Side Attester" in Background-Check model? If the TLS connection terminates outside of Attester, there are trivial attacks possible (e.g., in case of Confidential Computing).

issues.title: Coverage of the measurements/evidence
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
The draft (maybe in Sec Considerations) should say that not only does the TLS stack need to be covered by measurements, but also:

1. The code that performs the post-handshake phase must be measured, and...
2. There must be no other way to initiate generation of evidence except from signed code.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
I wonder if this should be part of the properties in the [use-cases draft](https://github.com/tls-attestation/use-cases-and-properties).

@thomas-fossati @muhammad-usama-sardar - thoughts?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> I wonder if this should be part of the properties in the [use-cases draft](https://github.com/tls-attestation/use-cases-and-properties).
> 
> [@thomas-fossati](https://github.com/thomas-fossati) [@muhammad-usama-sardar](https://github.com/muhammad-usama-sardar) - thoughts?

I am not sure.  How are these supposed to be achieved through pure protocol means?

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: True, don't think it's something we can design in, but I don't think they have to be strictly solvable like that. Maybe we can cover things that _need_ to go in the Security considerations as well.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Fair enough. Then I am fine with (also) adding it to the UC document.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Covered in #28 .

issues.title: Security Considerations: session resumption
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
Discussion with @yaronf, @thomas-fossati , @ionut-arm and Carsten: 

For Sec. 4.1. in draft-00 (Using the TLS Connection): 

**Background**: If the session drops due to some reason, one can do session resumption rather than complete handshake. 
**Problem**: There can be problems in session resumption if remote attestation has not already been done for that session. 
**Solution**:
First remote attestation MUST be done right after the initial handshake. This reduces the problem to essentially 1 round-trip time (for sending Authenticator Request and getting Authenticator) plus time for generation of Evidence and appraisal of Evidence. 

The next rounds of remote attestation can be done on need basis.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body:
Possible solution to avoid the race condition:
* Establish the handshake with explicit flags that prevent session resumption. (From the client side this can simply mean: delete the ticket before the handshake is complete.)
* Do remote attestation.
* Then enable session resumption. (Send a new `NewSessionTicket`.)

From a TLS handshake perspective this is possible. The question is whether APIs (specifically the OpenSSL API) support these operations and/or can be extended to do so.

issues.title: Terminology: EK in CertificateVerify
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
In RATS interim, Deb mentioned that ephemeral key in CertificateVerify for Authenticator is confusing. 
Clarify the terminology such that it does not contradict TLS.

More context: [interim notes](https://notes.ietf.org/notes-ietf-interim-2025-rats-01-rats#740---755-Identity-Crisis-in-Attested-TLS-for-Confidential-Computing)

We should define EK upfront in the terminology section.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
I like Deb's proposal of defining EK as "self-asserted" and saying the proof of possession is typically provided by self-signed cert. 

So define it like: 

- LTK = CA-certified Long-Term Key (used for server "authentication")
- EK = self-asserted Ephemeral Key (used for remote attestation)

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
Summary of discussion with @thomas-fossati, @ionut-arm and @tireddy2 (Please correct if I get something wrong and add if I missed something)

With Realm Personalization Value (RPV), it may be possible to identify the Realm. Hence, it may be possible to get rid of `EK` altogether. Post-handshake CertificateVerify message will then use the `LTK` as usual. 

All of this is under the assumption that `LTK` has been provisioned to the TEE.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Hmm, not sure if this issue is (still) relevant. The draft does not mention EK / "ephemeral" anywhere, so I assume it was part of your presentation?

issues.title: Security consideration: Relay attack
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
What prevents a malicious Attester from relaying the `certificate_request_context` to a genuine TEE and presenting the Evidence of that genuine TEE?
This question is not specific to `certificate_request_context` but applies in general to the draft (i.e., also to nonce, timestamp, epoch markers etc.).

Tiru's proposal: (discussed [here](https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/12#issuecomment-2844582521))
> one possible technique could be that the verifier will have to enforce policies that ensure the TEE producing the evidence is the one it expects, not just any valid TEE.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
I think we discussed this and the clarification in the security section should be two-fold:

* from a protocol perspective, the authenticator binds the attester's response to the current session
* from an RA perspective, the code handling this should be measured and appraised as per #11 

Tiru's proposal works in situations where the RP knows exactly which machine they're expecting to talk to, but that's not always the case.

issues.title: Misleading "Finished" Message
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body: I am not sure why do we have an arrow from Verifier to Server with "Finished" in [Fig. 1](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-fossati-tls-exported-attestation-02.html#figure-1)? I think it should be removed.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I agree that the Finished seems completely misplaced.

BTW, that’s not the only weird bit in Figure 1: the passport exchange should be shown before the handshake, rather than interwoven.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> the passport exchange should be shown before the handshake, rather than interwoven

As discussed with @ionut-arm, @yaronf and Carsten:
The key point is: What binds the attestation results to the handshake? This may be done using exporters as follows:

- Server puts `certificate_request_context` in AuthenticatorRequest (ClientCertificateRequest) 
- Client forwards that as `rdata` in Evidence to the Verifier
- Verifier puts `rdata` as part of the AR. (It might require changes in the Verifier to also reflect `rdata`)
- Client sends Exported Authenticator with AR containing the `rdata`
- Server can then check the AR which includes `certificate_request_context`

issues.title: IANA comments to -02
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
Before the IETF meeting, we check working group agendas for documents with IANA-related issues. We have notes about this document:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-fossati-tls-exported-attestation-02

1) In Table 1, “DTLS 1.3” should be changed to “DTLS-Only” to match the registry:

https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values

2) The registry “TLS Flags” hasn’t been created yet. Please add a reference to the document that’s going to create it. (The section currently has a link to the registry URL, but the registry isn’t there.)

Amanda Baber
IANA Operations Sr. Manager

issues.title: Ekr feedback on v2
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
> 
> I've now had a chance to look at this draft.
> 
> At a high level I have the same concerns I expressed over
> draft-fossati-tls-attestation, which is to say that it unclear what
> actual security properties that attestation provides. This draft is
> even more vague about this question. I appreciate that these
> properties are dependent on the precise configuration of the peer
> endpoint, and so there are presumably some specific assertions which
> need to appear in the attestation that describe that configuration,
> but I think the responsibility of this kind of draft is to explain
> what the implications of various choices are.
> 
> 
> In terms of the integration with TLS, I don't think the negotiation
> structure is quite right. Specifically, you indicate support for this
> mechanism with a CMW_Attestation flag in CH, which is then
> acknowledged in EE, but then you provide the actual data in a
> different extension (cmw_attestation) in Certificate. There are
> two problems here:
> 
> 1. You can't use flags this way.
> 2. CH is generally not the right place.
> 
> For point 1, draft-ietf-tls-tlsflags explicitly prohibits the use of a
> flag to signal an actual extension:
> 
> >    For a flag that does require a response, the only proper response is
> >    the same flag in a flags extension.  This extension MUST NOT be used
> >    to specify extensions where the response is a proper extension with
> >    content.
> 
> On point 2, here is what S 5.2 of RFC 9261 says:
> 
> >    ClientHello extensions are used to determine permissible extensions
> >    in the server's unsolicited Certificate message in order to follow
> >    the general model for extensions in (D)TLS in which extensions can
> >    only be included as part of a Certificate message if they were
> >    previously sent as part of a CertificateRequest message or
> >    ClientHello message.  This ensures that the recipient will be able to
> >    process such extensions.
> 
> As you are sending CertificateRequest and/or ClientCertificateRequest,
> that is where the offer has to appear. IOW, the correct design is
> to define only one extension, "cmw_attestation", which appears in
> CertificateRequest or ClientCertificateRequest respectively.
> 
> One more editorial point: you repeatedly refer to this as
> "post-handshake", but that's more properly used to refer to the
> mechanism in S 4.6.2 of RFC 8446. This mechanism isn't in TLS
> at all, but rather in the application protocol but bound to
> TLS.
> 
> -Ekr

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> At a high level I have the same concerns I expressed over
draft-fossati-tls-attestation, which is to say that it unclear what
actual security properties that attestation provides. 

As a starting point, the security considerations section can add a reference to the [paper](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/10373038), which covers two relevant Confidential Computing technologies in our context: Arm CCA and Intel TDX.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: The work has started [here](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-rats-sardar-sec-cons/).

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: Fixed in https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/31

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> At a high level I have the same concerns I expressed over
draft-fossati-tls-attestation, which is to say that it unclear what
actual security properties that attestation provides.

Added reference to paper on formal analysis in #48, which has security properties for attestation as well as attested TLS.

> One more editorial point: you repeatedly refer to this as
"post-handshake", but that's more properly used to refer to the
mechanism in S 4.6.2 of RFC 8446. This mechanism isn't in TLS
at all, but rather in the application protocol but bound to
TLS.

"Exported Authenticator-based post-handshake authentication" is the right terminology as per [RFC9261](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9261#section-1-4):

> Unlike renegotiation, Exported Authenticator-based post-handshake authentication does not require any changes at the TLS layer.

issues.title: Comments on draft charter
issues.author: mwiseman32
issues.body:
In first paragraph: We are enhancing the existing authentication. So should reverse the order: 
... in addition to conventional authentication (verification of identity), it's crucial to ensure that the peer's state is as expected.

2nd paragraph: In phrase:
such as proving that its software and firmware haven't been tampered with...
Attestation cannot "prove" that software / firmware hasn't been tampered with. It can only provide evidence of its identity. The verifier, using policy and manifests, make the decision about the software's trustworthiness.

2nd paragraph: Remove redundant "verifiable" 
Remote attestation ([RFC9334](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9334/)) addresses this by allowing an entity to produce Evidence about its current state.

2nd paragraph: Remove implementation implication. I realized this is stated as an example but this infers a hardware-based implementation.
...such as proving that its software and firmware haven't been tampered with, that secure boot is enabled, or that cryptographic keys are securely stored within a protected environment.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
Thank you Monty. 
> In first paragraph: We are enhancing the existing authentication. So should reverse the order: ... in addition to conventional authentication (verification of identity), it's crucial to ensure that the peer's state is as expected.
> 

Agree. 

> 2nd paragraph: In phrase: such as proving that its software and firmware haven't been tampered with... Attestation cannot "prove" that software / firmware hasn't been tampered with. It can only provide evidence of its identity. The verifier, using policy and manifests, make the decision about the software's trustworthiness.
> 

Mostly agree, except that attestation can provide evidence of state. Identity is related to authentication.
> 2nd paragraph: Remove redundant "verifiable" Remote attestation ([RFC9334](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9334/)) addresses this by allowing an entity to produce Evidence about its current state.
> 

What is "verifiable" redundant with?
> 2nd paragraph: Remove implementation implication. I realized this is stated as an example but this infers a hardware-based implementation. ...such as proving that its software and firmware haven't been tampered with, that secure boot is enabled, or that cryptographic keys are securely stored within a protected environment.

Indeed we are working with hardware-based attestation. So I think it should be fine.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Closing this issue as it has been settled.

issues.title: Ahmed's feedback on -02
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
> If we want to support continued trust across session lifetime or regain trust after a state transition then this seems like something we can already express using existing mechanisms since using Exported Authenticators (RFC 9261) with a cmw_attestation extension lets us carry session-bound attestation evidence after the handshake.
> 
> What’s worth calling out, though, is how standard EAT (RFC 9248) claims help enforce key properties depending on the verifiers policy:
> 
>     nonce → binds the evidence to the verifier's challenge and the TLS session,
>     iat / exp → allow the verifier to enforce a freshness window or session expiration window,
>     firmware_id, secboot, or similar → help the verifier evaluate platform state against known-trusted configuration.
> 
> 
> This gives the relying party enough structure to say: “I’ll continue trusting this session if the attestation was recent and the platform is still in a known-good state.”
> 
> If that’s no longer the case, for example, if the evidence has expired or the verifier has learned that the attested state is no longer acceptable then it can simply send a new CertificateRequest message. That triggers the peer to generate a fresh Exported Authenticator with updated attestation (or fail to do so), and the verifier can decide whether to continue the session or terminate it based on that result.
> 
> It might be helpful to include a concrete EAT-style example in the EXPATdraft, illustrating how claims like nonce, iat, and exp can support verifier-side policy, for example, enforcing evidence freshness, session binding, or attestation expiry. Since these claims are optional in EAT but highly relevant in this context, showing how they apply in the TLS Exported Authenticator setting would make the draft more implementer-friendly.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Ahmed [agreed on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/seal/gIyBfUJwBwbtD6_DkvYetkWMGjg/) that the security goals are already covered in our list. Hence, I prefer to go with the design that is undergoing thorough formal analysis rather than going for a completely new design.

issues.title: Ahmed's proposal (cnf claim)
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
Part of discussion in the [thread](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/attested-tls/IYPz5RGj3WnjruWEVUzkwjH7cmQ/):

> With cnf, the attestation includes the public TLS key. The Verifier can verify that the presented session key matches what’s in the evidence, ensuring that the entity being attested is the one actually controlling the TLS connection.
>  
>  
> Which is what I believe is what you and I are looking for:
> It is only the platform/TCB that could have produced the evidence given it is the only place where the attestation key exists.
> This attested evidence was indeed carried out by this specific session and this specific TLS key.
>  
> This addresses both conditions you mentioned:
>  
> The physical platform is in control of the TCB
> The TLS session terminates in a target environment/VM with the expected measurements
> And it avoids the ambiguity about who issued the certificate, since trust is anchored directly in the attestation evidence itself, not in external PKI.
> This same approach is already used in:
> OAuth 2.0 DPoP ([RFC 9449]) — to bind tokens to client-held keys
> ACE-OAuth ([RFC 9200]) — to enforce PoP in constrained IoT environments using CWT and cnf
> I think that the design is clear, secure, and available and would provide the missing link between attestation evidence and session key ownership for TLS EXPAT. I hope this clarifies it better.

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: This is out of context. If this is part of a public mail thread, please include a link.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: added link. I aslo don't understand what security goal it achieves, and in what ways it is better than our proposal.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Ahmed [agreed on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/seal/gIyBfUJwBwbtD6_DkvYetkWMGjg/) that the security goals are already covered in our list. Hence, I prefer to go with the design that is undergoing thorough formal analysis rather than going for a completely new design.

issues.title: When to start post-handshake
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: "Both peers can send an authenticator request message at any point after the handshake" - so this doesn't have to happen immediately? As a profile of 9261, we can say that we require the post-handshake exchange to start immediately after the TLS handshake completes.

issues.title: Top of Sec. 3 is confusing
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: The first sentences of Sec. 3 are very confusing with respect to TLS messages. It is never clear when we are referring to in-handshake messages (e.g. Certificate) or post-handshake. Yes, we do mention the "Authenticator message" but we could still make it clearer.

issues.title: What certificate chain?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: Sec. 3.2 assumes that there is always a certificate chain ready to be sent in the post-handshake exchange. Is it an exact copy of the TLS handshake's chain? If so, we should say so and mandate that the peer bitwise compares the two chains.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
We need to make it explicit that there are multiple possible options here:
* attester only has one identity, so the same certs are used; RP must verify they're identical (Need to spell out if the full chain from TLS handshake, or just the leaf cert)
* attester has multiple identities, other cert can be used, but the RP must be able to verify that identity

However this needs to be negotiated.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Regarding negotiation, the CertificateVerify in post-handshake should use the same signing alg as the main TLS handshake, which can limit what other identities are used post-handshake.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body:
Note: the secondary cert chain is not going to be for anchoring the AK, because that's bundled in the evidence wrapper.

Re. formal verification of multiple identities being served by same server, see Sec. cons section in RFC9261.

issues.title: Negotiation of the expat extension
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
Shouldn't `cmw_attestation` be negotiated in the initial handshake? It's a completely legitimate policy not to allow any traffic before the post-handshake exchange is complete. But to ensure it, you need earlier negotiation.

Nlte that the IANA section defines a flag but there's no text that uses it.

IMO we need to re-add text on flag-based negotiation in the TLS handshake, possibly followed by more detailed negotiation in the post-handshake.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Would be good to discuss how we negotiate this feature so that we avoid a wasted TLS handshake (e.g., ALPN)

issues.title: Format Negotiation
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
> However, applications using this mechanism still need to negotiate the encoding format (e.g., JOSE or COSE) and specify how attestation credentials are processed. This negotiation can be done via application-layer signaling or predefined profiles. Future specifications may define mechanisms to streamline this negotiation.

We are punting on format negotiation, but I think without even basic negotiation (JOSE vs COSE), it'll be hard to get basic interoperability. Per @thomas-fossati there are projects that have a way to do it, I guess we need to formalize the negotiation details.

issues.title: Attested CSR as a prerequisite
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: Sec. 5 (Security Considerations): do we really require [I-D.ietf-lamps-csr-attestation] as a prerequisite? If so then we are again in a place where freshness of the Evidence depends on the CA's latency. Note that the document says twice that we don't want CA-style latency.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: 2nd para in sec. 5 should probably be made into a "MAY" and converted into a separate subsection.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: I think the whole 2nd para should be removed. It opens up the same attacks that we want to avoid.

issues.title: Crypto binder definition
issues.author: ionut-arm
issues.body:
As discovered during prototyping, it seems the draft doesn't properly document how to achieve cryptographic binding between TLS connection and attestation evidence. See [this comment](https://github.com/tls-attestation/attestation-exported-authenticators/issues/8#issuecomment-3477875917) for source, though the contents are duplicated below.

The binding we need to achieve must rely on some sort of exported keying material that gets hash-linked into the evidence. The current draft, leveraging RFC9261, presumably describes a way to do this. We probably confused some of the details of 9261:

* The Handshake Context as defined in [sec. 5.1 of RFC9261](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9261#name-authenticator-keys) is an exporter value meant to be used in CertificateVerify and in the Finished messages.
* We seem to have considered [`certificate_request_context`](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9261#section-4-6.2) to be that binder, but it is NOT intended to work that way. It's just a nonce or, in any case, not something the peer should be able to compute on its own (from [sec. 4](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9261#name-authenticator-request): "The certificate_request_context SHOULD be chosen to be unpredictable to the peer (e.g., by randomly generating it)").

We likely mashed them up and considered `certificate_request_context` as an avenue through which an exported value is carried to the attester ([sec. 3.2 of expat draft](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-fossati-seat-expat-00#name-usage-in-exported-authentic)). There are two options to rectify this:

1. use `Handshake Context` for TLS <-> RA binding as well.
2. define a new exporter value with its own context and label.

Option (1) would be easier, but I'm not sure if that's good practice for a cryptographic value that's clearly scoped in the original doc.

@jhoyla - do you have any an opinion regarding these two options?

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body: Fixed in https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/43

issues.title: Pre-/intra- vs. post-handshake attestation
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
[Archive link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/seat/HE9QcPGrTArC0cKPcVw7tFnkh5U/)
Add a pointer to the paper in the Appendix to reason why we are standardizing post-handshake rather than intra-handshake

issues.title: Yuning's questions
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
[Archive link](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/seat/IuTQMmtOZw5McBYYuLhOb3sNHhY/)

> I’ve been reading both this draft [1] and the use case draft [2], and I have a few technical questions about how you envision some of the use cases to be realized using procedures mentioned in [1]:
> 
> - In Section 3.2 of the use-cases draft (“High-Assurance Command Execution”), the requirement is that the remote system must provide fresh attestation Evidence before a critical command is dispatched. Do you see this being realized purely by the application issuing an Exported Authenticator request on the existing TLS connection just before such commands, or do you expect any more fine-grained binding, e.g., including an operation/command identifier in certificate_request_context so that the attestation can be tied to a specific operation rather than only to the connection?
> 
>  - Across the three use cases in [2], where do you imagine the logic that decides when to trigger an EA-based attestation exchange typically residing?
> 
>     - inside the TLS stack or EA API implementation,
>     - in an application-layer middleware (e.g., a policy engine around the TLS exporter API), or
>     - in a higher-level orchestrator (e.g., a workload / network controller that coordinates several TLS connections)?

issues.title: Post-handshake data multiplexing
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
> To ensure that the attested peer continues to operate in a secure state, remote attestation may be re-initiated periodically. In this protocol, this can be accomplished by initiating a new Exported-Authenticator–based post-handshake authentication exchange, which results in a new certificate_request_context and therefore a newly derived exporter value to maintain freshness.

After the handshake, the TLS connection is used to transmit unstructured data in both directions. If the same connection is also to be used to transmit signaling messages (a.k.a. post-handshake authentication exchange), there must be a way to distinguish the "normal" TLS-protected data from these messages.

pulls.title: Initial review of Introduction
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body:
- I tend to disagree with the following sentence because the role of Verifier is the same in both models. It depends on the order of data flow. 
> These interactions can follow different models, such as the passport or background check model, depending on the role of a verifier in the system.
- The text regarding RFC 9261 in the draft was very confusing to me. Particularly, we need to distinguish between Exported Authenticator and Authenticator Request. I made some initial changes. Please check.

pulls.title: More security considerations
pulls.author: yaronf
pulls.body: This is not very polished, but there are security considerations to do with attestation at the application level.

pulls.title: Remove trailing space - get lint to pass
pulls.author: yaronf

comments.body:
```suggestion
This document inherits the security considerations of RFC 9261 and RFC 9334. The integrity of the exported authenticators must be guaranteed, and any failure in validating Evidence SHOULD be treated as a fatal error in the communication channel. Additionally, in order to benefit from remote attestation, it is recommended that Evidence MUST be protected using dedicated attestation keys chaining back to a trust anchor. This trust anchor will typically be provided by the hardware manufacturer.
```
we either recommend or require.  doing both is confusing.

I will go for the latter. In my analysis, once the TIK is lost, an unprotected (e.g., unsigned) evidence is available to the adversary. Hence, remote attestation does not bring any security benefit in this case. One might argue it is even worse than standard TLS because using ephemeral key breaks the authentication property as well (something still to be argued more formally).
makes sense to require.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: This small PR has been pending for 2 months. I will merge it tomorrow unless someone objects.
This is incorrect now 😛 In case you're willing to make this change too
Fixed, thanks.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
What prevents a malicious Attester from relaying the `certificate_request_context` to a genuine TEE and presenting the Evidence of that genuine TEE?
This question is not specific to `certificate_request_context` but applies in general to the draft (i.e., also to nonce, timestamp, epoch markers etc.).

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> What prevents a malicious Attester from relaying the `certificate_request_context` to a genuine TEE and presenting the Evidence of that genuine TEE?
> This question is not specific to `certificate_request_context` but applies in general to the draft (i.e., also to nonce, timestamp, epoch markers etc.).

Good question, one possible technique could be that the verifier will have to enforce policies that ensure the TEE producing the evidence is the one it expects, not just any valid TEE.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> Good question, one possible technique could be that the verifier will have to enforce policies that ensure the TEE producing the evidence is the one it expects, not just any valid TEE.

I am very skeptical of putting things into policies. Such policies are likely to be forgotten. So if we have no good answer, we should maybe put it in security considerations. But I can open a separate issue on this as it is not specific to this PR (and applies to older draft with nonce as well). 

In general, this PR looks good to me. Would like to have a short discussion to understand a couple of things in the next meeting, otherwise it's good to merge.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > Good question, one possible technique could be that the verifier will have to enforce policies that ensure the TEE producing the evidence is the one it expects, not just any valid TEE.
> 
> I am very skeptical of putting things into policies. Such policies are likely to be forgotten. So if we have no good answer, we should maybe put it in security considerations. But I can open a separate issue on this as it is not specific to this PR (and applies to older draft with nonce as well).

please raise a PR for this issue, it needs to be discussed.

> 
> In general, this PR looks good to me. Would like to have a short discussion to understand a couple of things in the next meeting, otherwise it's good to merge.

Thanks, I will merge the PR.
In my reading of RFC 9261, Authenticator consists of Certificate, CertificateVerify, and Finished messages and not Certificate message alone. Please correct me if I am wrong.

[Sec 5.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9261#section-5.2)
> An authenticator is formed from the concatenation of TLS 1.3 Certificate, CertificateVerify, and Finished messages [[RFC8446](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8446)].

and [5.2.4](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9261#section-5.2.4)
> Certificate || CertificateVerify || Finished
Fixed

An editorial note: Ideally, RATS CMW should only introduce what it is. It should not mention RFC9261 or try to do any combination of specifications, since the text above says: 
> This document builds upon three foundational specifications:
The last two lines are supposed to be in a separate paragraph, fixed it.
I think Authenticator Request does not have any freshness. Why is the nonce removed? How is evidence freshness ensured?

In this case, freshness is inherently provided by the certificate_request_context in the authenticator request.  A certificate_request_context value MUST be unique for each authenticator request within the scope of a connection.
okay, that sounds fine to me.

Minor editorial: to be consistent with `Authenticator Request (ClientCertReq)`, I'll propose 
`Exported Authenticator (Certificate with cmw_attestation, CertificateVerify, Finished)`
Fixed.

This line specifically calls out attestation evidence instead of attestation information (like in line 110). Is this on purpose? I can see that line 136 also carries on with background check only.

Note: maybe we can keep a consistent terminology and use `remote attestation credentials` or `attestation credentials`, like the other draft. "Attestation information" seems a bit more vague.

`Background Check Model` here, and `Passport Model` on line 161.

Same for lines 170 and 175.
Could we collapse this and the same write-up from above, and use `relying party` and `attester`, and just say that each of the roles are fulfilled by one or both parties?

Similar to the section on `Usage in Post-Handshake Authentication`, this seems to be specific to evidence and I'm not sure if this is on purpose and the passport model is skipped for some unspecified reason? (old text seems to mention both)
Thanks, updated to use "attestation credentials".
Good catch, fixed.
Good point, fixed.
Thanks, fixed.

pulls.title: Updated draft for clarity on the new extension
pulls.author: tireddy2

reviews.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
reviews.body: needs some clarity on attested CSR

comments.body: Which "attestation information": Evidence or Attestation Results?
s/an sequence/a sequence
Editorial: This paragraph breaks the flow. Preferably move this paragraph to the end of this section.
While the older statement was meant to be for both background check and passport model, I think the new text on CSR attestation is applicable only for passport model.
Evidence or Attestation Results, updated text.
Fixed.
Agreed, moved paragraph.
Good catch, fixed.

A bit hard to digest. Prefer to simplify the construction: 
`This document introduces an extension, namely cmw_attestation, to the TLS Certificate message which ... `

```suggestion
This document introduces a new TLS certificate message extension called cmw_attestation.
This extension allows Attestation Evidence or Attestation Results to be included in the extensions field of the end-entity certificate in the TLS Certificate message.
```
Yeah, that’s pretty hefty.  See [0982fb3](https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/18/commits/0982fb3d4656646e6604c50af5223dcc8d50295c)
LGTM, thank you!

pulls.title: CMW Extension and terminology
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body:
- Terminology and Capitalization of terms
- CMW applies only to Certificate message of Authenticator

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: @hannestschofenig @ionut-arm could you please have a look?
It's never a good idea to depend on another I-D. Unless "bis" adds something important here, let's keep the dependency on the original RFC.
Same as above, keep 8446.

Not sure about such a strong statement as "never". At least I have one recent counterexample [here](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/rUK8UrkREY025QMDuDPOXHma_Ek/) from the AD review of 8773bis: 

> Update all references of RFC8446 to 8446bis 

Also, 8446bis has had several last calls.

This (and all the other instances of the same phrase) sounds odd.

I suggest replacing “_to Certificate Message of Authenticator_” with “_to the Authenticator's Certificate message_"

I agree with Yaron. Unless the BIS contains information we rely on critically, there is no reason to change the reference until RFC8446 becomes obsolete (which will happen as soon as the BIS gets its RFC number).

The typical way to address this in kramdown-rfc is to create an alias, e.g.:
```
RFC8446: tls13
```
and move the concrete reference when obsoletion kicks in:
```
RFCXXXX: tls13
```

Are you sure? Seems to me this should be:

`tls13: RFC8446`

I believe it is as I suggested above.  Then, in the markdown, you reference as `{{-tls13}}`.  See, for example, https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-reference-interaction-models/pull/71/files

```suggestion
As defined in {{Section 4.4.2 of -tls13}}, the TLS Certificate message consists of a certificate_list, which is a sequence of CertificateEntry structures. Each CertificateEntry contains a certificate and a set of associated extensions. The cmw_attestation extension MUST appear only in the first CertificateEntry of the Certificate message and applies exclusively to the end-entity certificate. It MUST NOT be included in entries corresponding to intermediate or trust anchor certificates. This design ensures that attestation information is tightly bound to the entity being authenticated.
```

This breaks the build:

```suggestion
- Certificate validation (e.g., signature verification, revocation checks) MUST still be performed according to TLS {{-tls13}} and PKIX {{!RFC5280}}.
```

pulls.title: Remove misleading "Finished" message (Fixes #21)
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body: Remove misleading "Finished" message from Verifier to server in passport model

comments.body: I take it there's no `Finished` from Server to Client?

> there's no Finished from Server to Client?

Yes, there is no Finished from Server to Client in post-handshake exchange based on RFC9261 (unless Server is the Attester).

pulls.title: Security and privacy considerations
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body: From older draft with some updates

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: The build is currently broken.  I’ll push a fix shortly, please avoid pushing further commits in the meantime.  Thanks!

ref fix

```suggestion
The Evidence carried in cmw_attestation does not require an additional freshness mechanism, such as a nonce {{RA-TLS}} or timestamp, since freshness is inherently provided by the certificate_request_context in the authenticator request.
```
While this information is good and useful, I don't think it belongs here.  Let's move it to the appendix or another document.
Moved the comparison parts to Appendix.

We should give it a proper title.

As is, it renders as “Appendix X. Appendix”, which is not what we want.

While you are at it, please add `{:unnumbered}` between L370 and L371.
Can you please add `Identity Key` to the terminology section? Don't think we define it anywhere.

reviews.author: ionut-arm
reviews.body: I've added a few minor comments, otherwise looks good.

comments.body: Is that `[RA-TLS]` at the end correct syntax? I'm probably still clueless about how this format works...

```suggestion
The privacy implications are similar to OCSP {{-ocsp}}.
```
(first letter in OCSP stands for "online")
Does this not apply to client-as-atteser as well (the ability to check the identity of the peer first)? Because this paragraph makes it sound like only the server can check.
It should be `{{RA-TLS}}`

```suggestion
In background-check model, the Verifier not only has access to detailed information about the Attester's TCB through Evidence, but it also knows the exact time and the party (i.e., the RP) with whom the secure channel establishment is attempted {{RA-TLS}}.
```

```suggestion
# Acknowledgements
{:unnumbered}

We would like to thank Chris Patton for his proposal to explore RFC 9261 for attested TLS.
We would also like to thank Paul Howard and Yogesh Deshpande for their input.

# Post-handshake vs Intra-handshake Privacy
```

```suggestion
For the case of the TLS server as the Attester, the server can ask for client authentication and only send the Evidence after successful client authentication. This limits the exposure of server's hardware-level Claims to be revealed only to authorized clients. A client running as an Attester can similarly rely on the server's authentication to limit exposure of its attestation credential to authorized servers.
```

I think the comparison to OCSP does not hold, because an OCSP server may be a total "third party", whereas the Verifier is typically strongly associated with the RP. So for example, attester-side redaction is not effective because if you don't trust the Verifier, you shouldn't trust the RP either.

This may be true, but if the client also needs to be attested, then you have the same problem with the client's Evidence, no? And in fact from a privacy POV the client's Evidence is a lot more sensitive (because clients represent individuals more than servers do.)

> This may be true, but if the client also needs to be attested, then you have the same problem with the client's Evidence, no?

The point here is that if the client also needs to be attested, then in post-HS, the server has the opportunity to at least authenticate the client before the server sends its Evidence. In intra-HS, the server cannot apply such a filter.

> And in fact from a privacy POV the client's Evidence is a lot more sensitive (because clients represent individuals more than servers do.)

I agree. I will rephrase to clarify that the comparison here is from the server's view.

> […] the Verifier is typically strongly associated with the RP

s/typically/sometimes/
@thomas-fossati Can you give a counterexample where this makes sense, i.e. where an RP blindly trusts a Verifier even though they are not within the same trust domain?
Isn't it RFC6960?
Agree, working on it.
I am accepting the removal of "online". We can continue the discussion on the rest.

I think the rest of this section is about Client as Attester and only this paragraph is about Server as Attester. If you agree, I propose to add `## Server as Attester` on top of this paragraph and `## Client as Attester` in the beginning.
Resolving it for now. Reopen if you think it is not correct.
I am not aware of any deployment where session keys are stored in TEE/HSM; only the private key of the end-entity certificate will be stored in TEE.

Which deployments are you aware of? Probably the ones you are aware of are doing completely different stuff.

- Where is the TLS connection terminated in these deployments?
It was never used in the whole draft. So instead of defining it, I tried to clarify by saying "identity key used for TLS handshake".
@tireddy2 An example here would be an AWS Enclave which can run arbitrary software (basically any container) and is running a TLS stack.
Got it, Thanks.
Could you group the entries below, like [here](https://github.com/ietf-wg-jose/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt/blob/main/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt.md?plain=1#L539)
I consulted with ChatGPT about SELF/RFCThis and it referenced another of your drafts... Anyway, please add "Note to RFC Editor: replace RFCThis by...".
@thomas-fossati is away until the cutoff, I'll fix this (and the merge conflicts) before release.
Done! See above

pulls.title: Fix "key attestation" text
pulls.author: ionut-arm
pulls.body:
Key Attestation as a mechanism is not required for our use-case and complicates the picture. Removing it for now at least.

Fixes #7

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
See https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/issues/7#issuecomment-3410129282 

I am happy to remove this — especially in this context, which does not seem particularly suitable.
But the property of “key attestation” must be stated somewhere else.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: OK! New text has dropped, let me know if it sounds good.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: @muhammad-usama-sardar I'm happy to close this since #28 covers what I wanted to convey (or will cover), but I'd prefer it if you also remove those uses of "key attestation" throughout the document, and leave it only as a security consideration.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: I removed all instances of key attestation in #28. I don't think it is required in security considerations. My point in the original issue was that it is an ambiguous term and we should avoid it.

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: Ah, yes, nevermind, I didn't notice that you'd removed them in your PR too.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: Not sure the “Fixes #7” is the right tag.  I’d say “Partly addresses #7” instead.

comments.body: The title of this PR is "nix key attestation", but then you talk about the key being trustworthy. I think the key is neither attested nor is it trustworthy; it is the *platform* that's attested and becomes trustworthy.

This paragraph is somewhat weak: do we have an opinion on whether the platform needs to provide evidence as part of the key being certified?

Also, these guarantees (the private key is securely stored etc.) are subject to the same caveats as the Security Guarantees section being added in PR #28.
Contrary to title of PR, "key attestation" is still in use.

Ok, fixed the title, forgot to do it after the first re-write of the PR...

> I think the key is neither attested nor is it trustworthy; it is the platform that's attested and becomes trustworthy.

I guess this is a philosophical debate, whether "delegation" in the RA context translates into trustworthiness extension. For example, is a confidential workload trustworthy given that the platform has been appraised as trustworthy? Isn't RA just an exercise in propagating trustworthiness from RoT upwards in a software stack? That's my point of view - the code that "blessed" the key is trustworthy, so why wouldn't the key be?
Yeah, that was an oversight on my side, the initial patch was removing key attestation altogether.

I think the difference is that for platform and workload, the Verifying Relying Party has Reference Values. But for this key, it has nothing to compare against. That's why I believe "Key attestation" is not attestation, really.

I'm a bit confused by the last sentence:

> Endpoints that do not recognize the cmw_attestation extension in a request MUST ignore it.

Presumably if the endpoint does not recognize cmw_attestation it's because this document is not something that was considered, so the `MUST` is not enforceable. Is this just the standard way to write up such extensions?

It is discussed in Section 9.3 of RFC8446 which says:
   -  A server receiving a ClientHello MUST correctly ignore all
      unrecognized cipher suites, extensions, and other parameters.
      Otherwise, it may fail to interoperate with newer clients.  In
      TLS 1.3, a client receiving a CertificateRequest or
      NewSessionTicket MUST also ignore all unrecognized extensions.

Fixed text as follows:
As specified in {{Section 9.3 of RFC8446}}, endpoints that do not recognize the cmw_attestation extension in a CertificateRequest or ClientCertificateRequest MUST ignore it and continue processing the message as if the extension were absent.
I don't think it is a useful change. You are explaining "TLS Exported Authenticators" via "Exported Authenticator-based" which is cyclic and does not help the readers with anything.

```suggestion
- TLS Exported Authenticators {{RFC9261}}: It offers bi-directional post-handshake authentication. Once a TLS connection is established, both peers can send an authenticator request message at any point after the handshake. This message from the server and the client uses the CertificateRequest and the ClientCertificateRequest messages, respectively. The peer receiving the authenticator request message can respond with an Authenticator consisting of Certificate, CertificateVerify, and Finished messages. These messages can then be validated by the other peer.
```

comments.author: ionut-arm
comments.body: This PR also takes care of renaming for the new WG

pulls.title: Cryptographic Binding of the Evidence to the TLS Session
pulls.author: tireddy2

comments.body:
I think this needs some expanding:
```suggestion
The attester MUST include the exporter value in the attestation evidence, either exactly as produced or hash-linked along with other claims if needed.
```
... but given this ambiguity, I wonder if we should explicitly define how that hash-linking must look.

hmm, not sure how this should work. RP ideally doesn't dig into attestation evidence, and if the binder and nonce (which might be coming from the Verifier) have to be hash-linked, then the Verifier needs the binder to check that the nonce is correct. Will mull it over, I think we had some text describing something similar in the intra- draft.

I fixed text as follows:
To allow verification, the TLS endpoint that receives the attestation evidence MUST compute the exporter value using the same exporter invocation described for the attester. This value is then provided to the Relying Party as part of the attestation validation. The RP compares the value supplied by the TLS endpoint with the value included in the attestation evidence; if they differ, the attestation evidence MUST be rejected.

I did not specify hashing of the exporter value because it would require defining a hash algorithm and add unnecessary complexity. Using the exporter value exactly as produced keeps the mechanism simple and ensures straightforward verification.

Agree with that when it's possible, but lots of platforms and attestation interfaces only provide you with one input value that gets baked into the attestation evidence (e.g., TPM2.0 Quotes, Arm CCA realm tokens, Intel TDX too IIRC), which means if you have both this binder and a nonce from the verifier for freshness you can't fulfil both.

The hash algo shouldn't be a problem - we can just take whatever was negotiated at TLS handshake level.

We can use the exporter value as the sole freshness and binding input. This avoids requiring both a binder and a separate nonce. The exporter value is already derived using the hash function, see RFC 8446, Section 7.5, so hashing it again does not provide any additional benefit and adds complexity.

> If the TLS endpoint does not perform this check itself, it MUST convey the computed exporter value to the Relying Party (RP) so that the RP can perform the comparison as part of attestation validation.

Confused: isn't the TLS endpoint here the same entity as the RP? Also, I'm not sure it's secure to convey the exporter (to a Verifier) as-is, you probably want one more round of hashing.

I meant the verifier which validates the attestation evidence, replaced RP with "verifier". The exporter value is hashed based on the inputs 
a) label which is set to "Attestation Binding" 
b) context is set to certificate_request_context 
c) exporter_master_secret
Because this value is the output of a one-way hash function, it cannot be used to recover the exporter_master_secret.

We can use the exporter value as the sole freshness and binding input. This avoids requiring both a binder and a nonce and ensures the mechanism works across platforms. The exporter value is derived using a hash function, see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8446#section-7.5) for details. I don't see a need to do hashing of the exporter value again.

reviews.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
reviews.body: needs some clarity on key name and `rdata`

comments.body: There is no key with the name `exporter_master_secret` in TLS specs. Please be precise on that from RFC8446bis.
Prefer a shorter label "ra binder"
Userdata such as (`rdata` field of TEEs like SGX, TDX, and others) seems to be missing in this proposal.
Can be phrased better. Will think about some text.

Particularly `The TLS endpoint can verify the exporter binding directly` is not good statement. Only after reading the whole text, the reader sees that the `can` is because it can offload it to a verifier.
Our draft refers to RFC8446, it needs to be updated to refer to RFC8446bis in a separate PR.
TLS 1.3 allows a maximum size of 255 for label.
Sure, go ahead and propose text.

I'm surprised. While RFC 9261 does not define its own exporter, I thought we would be using something that's readily available at the application layer (namely, the Authenticator) rather than defining our own exporter, which would require a change to the TLS stack.

"rdata" is not relevant for the cryptographic binding defined in the draft. The binding mechanism operates over the attestation evidence as an opaque blob, regardless of whether a specific TEE includes fields like rdata.

RFC 9261 also invokes the existing TLS exporter API using its own label and context to derive the handshake context. We are simply using the standard exporter interface with a different label, exactly the same approach that RFC 9261 follows.
RFC8446bis has agreement and is in final stages. So preferably move it to RFC8446bis within this.
Done.

```suggestion
To allow verification, the TLS endpoint that receives the attestation evidence MUST compute the exporter value using the same exporter invocation described for the attester. The TLS endpoint MUST either verify the exporter binding directly or offload it to Verifier. For the former, it MUST reject the attestation evidence when the values do not match. For the latter, it MUST convey the computed exporter value to the verifier so that it can perform the comparison as part of attestation validation.
```

what about this?

reviews.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
reviews.body: Small rephrase; rest we can discuss on Monday.

comments.body:
```suggestion
* the certificate_request_context from the CertificateRequest message as the context value (`context_value` as defined in Section 7.5 of RFC8446bis).
```

Based on meeting:  (Attendees: Ionut, Thomas, Tiru, Yuning, Carsten, Usama, Yaron, Meiling Chen)

Define key_length: Ionut may share some thoughts here. 

Yaron's proposal: Maybe formal is better, something like:
   `TLS-Exporter("Attestation Binding", certificate_request_context, key_length)`
See also https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-fossati-tls-attestation-08#section-6.2.1

Yaron: MUST needs to be changed. 
Tiru will look into MUST terminology.

Regarding the length, the place I was reading about it recently was in the epoch markers I-D, see [this](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-rats-epoch-markers-02#name-nonce-requirements) section. Only gives upper and lower bound, not sure I have much of a recommendation beyond that.
Formally, I think this depends on exactly which hash function you're using in the TEE. Practically, you can't go wrong with 32 bytes.
Agreed, updated draft to use 32 bytes.

I thought it implies automatically from #34, no? Anyway, reverted and merged in #46.

I believe what's creating more confusion is which draft is vulnerable, and which one is not. But if you are fine with that compared to small history that this document has, I am fine with it.

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: I don’t approve it, and not because it’s my name or someone else's, but because there is no reason to do that and it will only create confusion (with searches, tracking doc history, etc.)

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Self-merging based on [this](https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/44#pullrequestreview-3525805516)
`rdata` includes the (hash of) public key. This should be in the design rather than a security consideration.
Updated text to convey hash of the pubic key in the evidence. I have placed it before the security considerations section.

pulls.title: Intra- vs. post-HS security and some cleanup #23 and #42
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body:
- added formal analysis in Appendix
- Binding is orthogonal to cmw_extension, so should be a separate section
- Exporter invocation does not need to define it.
- s/session/connection

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
Based on discussion with @tireddy2 and @fish_42
We agree: Binding is orthogonal to cmw_extension, so should be a separate section
- Move binding section after sec. 4
- Agreed exporter invocation does not need to define it.
- Add ref to fossati-tls-attestation in Appendix

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: @tireddy2 @ionut-arm @thomas-fossati @yaronf @hannestschofenig @fish_42 Updated as per [discussion](https://github.com/tls-attestation/exported-attestation/pull/48#issuecomment-3737597795) in meeting today. Please have a look.
